papers.title: The struggle for trans rights has parallels to that for gay rights
papers.desc: But also differs in significant ways, writes Adam Smith, The Economist’s audience-engagement editor

papers.title: The boss of Pakistan’s ruling party is sentenced to ten years in jail
papers.desc: Nawaz Sharif says it is all an army-inspired ploy to prevent his PML-N winning this month’s election

papers.title: Italy’s government proposes to limit fixed-term job contracts
papers.desc: A new law reverses recent reforms and highlights the government’s split personality

papers.title: Companies appear to be gaining market power
papers.desc: That may mean lower pay for workers, and less innovation

papers.title: Is the World Cup really free from doping?
papers.desc: No player has failed a test since 1994. But the sport has been marred by drug scandals

papers.title: Ukraine wants a national church that is not beholden to Moscow
papers.desc: Arguments over church authority could reopen centuries-old wounds

papers.title: Changing the concept of “woman” will cause unintended harms
papers.desc: There are more things to consider than some trans activists would have you believe, argues Kathleen Stock, an academic

papers.title: I am neither trans nor a woman. Can I write about the issues they face?
papers.desc: In a representative democracy, what I share with women and trans people is more important than our identities, writes James Kirkup, Director of the Social Market Foundation
